report_title: Industry Report on Media Streaming and Broadcasting
executive_summary: The media streaming and broadcasting industry has faced challenges as demand for airtime and advertising expenditures wavered, and the number of cable TV subscriptions fell significantly. However, these hindrances were offset by a boom in online video streaming and surge in demand for media content. Significant consolidation occurred, with large traditional cable and TV providers expanding into streaming. Over the past five years, revenue climbed at a CAGR of 0.8% to $212.9 billion in 2024, with profit reaching 14.7%. Over the next five years, revenue is forecast to grow at a CAGR of 2.1% to $236.7 billion, with profit inching up to 15.0% in 2029.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The trend of cord-cutting accelerated, pressuring cable networks to adapt. Major players acquired streaming platforms. The online streaming boom led to industry revenue climbing at a CAGR of 0.8% over the past five years to $212.9 billion in 2024, with profit reaching 14.7%.

Streaming services' subscription fees are more affordable than cable TV. Short-form video content is easier to produce and attracts more advertising. Cable networks rely more on website ads and branded content as advertisers shift online.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: A Variety of Content for Every Market
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Major streaming services invest heavily in original content. Niche services target specific genres. International expansion involves localization. Live TV streaming options gained popularity.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Traditional Industry Enterprises Look to Diversify
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Cable providers launched streaming platforms to battle siphoned demand. Disney acquired Fox and Hulu, CBS merged with Viacom, AT&T's Warner Media merged with Discovery.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Oversaturation may limit growth, driving larger companies to acquire niche platforms. Content fragmentation could lead to bundling or partnerships between platforms.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Traditional Services are Expected to Expand Further into the Streaming Realm
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Streaming dominance will continue as consumers opt for on-demand content. Cable/TV providers will adopt hybrid models offering live and on-demand streaming.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: As media streaming providers continue to crack down on password and account sharing, the industry will undergo an expansion to its potential market.
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Cable networks must adapt by embracing streaming, offering flexible options, and exploring new revenue streams beyond traditional advertising.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Technological Innovations Drive the Industry Forward
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Streaming services will invest in higher quality formats, content delivery networks, AI for personalized recommendations, and other innovations.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry provide media streaming distribution services, operate social network sites, operate media broadcasting and cable television networks, and supply information to the news media. Most products and services are offered through subscription-based platforms.

positive_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: high - increasing

key_trends: Price competition is rampant among providers, stemming from the increasing number of services available.
Acquisition activity expanded product offerings, with many companies setting their goals on streaming services.

The shift to media streaming has energized the industry. Many traditional cable network providers have pivoted to developing their own streaming services to circumvent the loss of demand from cord-cutting trends.
Multiple companies entering the industry have led to increased competition among the top streaming platforms.
Traditional media companies are looking for avenues into streaming and many are acquiring or starting a streaming venture of their own.
More mobile phones with internet connections have made it easier for consumers to access video streaming, leading to more subscriptions.
High cable costs have deterred consumers from purchasing traditional subscriptions.
Bidding wars have driven up the prices of licensing rights for popular shows and movies.
Many streaming platforms periodically raise their subscription prices to reflect the added value of new content or cover rising production and licensing costs.
Strategic licensing deals can be lucrative.
New York houses the largest companies involved in traditional TV and cable services.
High-skilled labor is crucial to media streaming and content production operations.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Streaming services licensed content from cable networks initially garnered demand from the younger population under 30.
Consumers aged 18 to 49 make up a significant portion of the consumer base.
Consumers 30 years and older tend to have more established and financially stable households.
Older consumers are still learning to use the rapidly evolving changes to video streaming services.

products_and_services.product_description: Media streaming is a broad segment consisting of paid subscriptions and ad revenue specifically related to media streaming services.
Licensing of rights to broadcast or distribute Content comprises more than half of industry revenue.
TV airtime is the most considerable portion of revenue for content providers.
Radio airtime consists of the same subsegments as television airtime.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Other Content (News Publishing, Production, Other Media Content)
products_and_services.product_description: The remainder of industry revenue is generated from various smaller sources.

tier_1_suppliers: Movie & Video Distribution in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Video Postproduction Services in the US
tier_1_buyers: Media Buying Agencies in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Media streaming and content providers accumulate a lot of revenue from selling advertising spots that air nationwide to viewers.
Higher consumer spending leads to more money for entertainment, such as video streaming.

business_locations.location_description: States like Georgia have become hubs of film and television production due to generous incentives implemented by the state.
California is home to the Silicon Valley region outside of San Francisco, home to many multinational tech companies and startups.
Similar to the West, the Mid-Atlantic is home to highly populated cities.
New England is home to Harvard and MIT, two prestigious universities.

regulations_points.regulation_description: No new cable operator may provide service without a franchise.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984
regulations_points.regulation_description: Policies for franchise provisions and renewals, subscriber rates, etc.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Act addressed numerous issues including surging cable service rates.
The commission's authority to control the rates charged terminated.

basis_points.basis_title: Price competition is rampant among providers
basis_points.basis_description: Price competition is rampant among providers, stemming from the increasing number of services available.

basis_points.basis_title: Pirating remains the most prominent threat
basis_points.basis_description: Pirating remains the most prominent threat to enterprises since it allows customers to view the content for free.
Acquisition activity expanded product offerings, with many companies setting their goals on streaming services.

basis_points.basis_title: Differentiation a vital point of emphasis
basis_points.basis_description: Mounting competition has made differentiation a vital point of emphasis, with original content being a big deciding factor in customer acquisition and retention.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Traditional Companies Expand into the Streaming Space
concentration_points.concentration_description: Traditional enterprises in the TV and cable sub-industries have expanded into video and media streaming.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Acquisitions Across the Industry Have Helped Providers Grow Their Product Offering
concentration_points.concentration_description: Disney took over Twenty-First Century Fox, cementing its lead in video entertainment.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases Grow as Operators Providers Expand Content Offerings
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Many providers have looked to expand their content catalogs.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wages Remain High as Competition Grows
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The need for skilled labor remains as cable and media streaming providers look.
The high cost of acquiring customers greatly impacts profitability.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Labor is minimal in comparison with the capital needed.
Digital transmission has set the stage for major advancements.

volatility_points.volatility_title: High prices deter consumers from purchasing cable subscriptions
volatility_points.volatility_description: Cable subscriptions are significantly more expensive than streaming services.

volatility_points.volatility_title: LIMITED OFFERINGS BY CABLE NETWORKS PRESSURE DEMAND
volatility_points.volatility_description: Cable subscriptions have plunged in recent years.

volatility_points.volatility_title: EASE OF ACCESS PLAYS A BIG ROLE
volatility_points.volatility_description: Streaming services are accessible on mobile devices.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Leisure Time Leads to More Activity
volatility_points.volatility_description: Streaming services are a popular pastime for consumers.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Different Plans to Appeal to a Large Market

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Platforms use AI-driven algorithms to suggest content.

FAQs.question: How have changes in consumer preferences and electronic usage habits changed your operations?
FAQs.answer: Greater cell phone and tablet use has positively impacted demand for industry products.

FAQs.question: How has your company's marketing and advertising expenditure affected demand for your services?
FAQs.answer: With good investment and product marketing, companies can develop new niche markets.

FAQs.question: How do your depreciation and R&D spending levels compare with your competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Depreciation costs are often extensive for operators with a large user base.

FAQs.question: Does the impact of large globalized companies affect your operational costs?
FAQs.answer: The industry is dominated by multiple technology giants.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology?
FAQs.answer: Companies are using more advanced data centers for reliable streams.

FAQs.question: Are you or your competitors experiencing scrutiny from litigation or public and government scrutiny?
FAQs.answer: Several technology giants have faced scrutiny for the use and storage of consumer data.

FAQs.question: How important is it to be adaptable in this industry?
FAQs.answer: Companies must be flexible in altering their goods and services since streaming services move quickly.
